page.title: Islamic view of the Pharaoh of the Exodus

rev.diff:

* "Then he (Firaun) collected (his men) and made a proclamation, Saying, "I am your Lord, Most High". [Qur'an 79:23-24]
* "Then he (Firaun) collected (his men) and made a proclamation, Saying, "I am your Lord, Most High". [Qur'an 79:23-24]

According to EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica, "The Egyptians believed their Pharaoh to be a god, identifying him with the sky god Horus and with the sun gods Re, Amon, and Aton." and that "The Pharaoh's divine status was believed to endow him with magical powers: ... he was able to trample thousands of the enemy on the battlefield, and he was all-powerful, knowing everything and controlling nature and fertility."<ref>"Pharaoh" in Encyclopaedia Britannica Ultimate Reference Suite 2004 DVD, Â© 1994â2004 Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc.</ref> While pharaohs believed they were divine, some of them believed themselves to be higher even than the gods, one of them was [[Ramesses II]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} Only [[Akhenaten]] was a monotheist and he believed the only god was [[Aten]], not himself.
+
According to EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica, "The Egyptians believed their Pharaoh to be a god, identifying him with the sky god Horus and with the sun gods Re, Amon, and Aton." and that "The Pharaoh's divine status was believed to endow him with magical powers: ... he was able to trample thousands of the enemy on the battlefield, and he was all-powerful, knowing everything and controlling nature and fertility."<ref>"Pharaoh" in [[Encyclopaedia Britannica Ultimate Reference Suite 2004 DVD]], Â© 1994â2004 Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc.</ref> While pharaohs believed they were divine, some of them believed themselves to be higher even than the gods, one of them was [[Ramesses II]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} Only [[Akhenaten]] was a monotheist and he believed the only god was [[Aten]], not himself.
Recent discoveries in the tomb of Amenhotep III, the father of Akhenaten have revealed that this pharaoh, in his lifetime, declared himself to be the living embodiment of the entire pantheon of Egyptian Gods. In this statement, the pharaoh does not disregard the other Gods, but declares himself as the embodiment of those Gods - hence no other god do I know for you but myself.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}}
Recent discoveries in the tomb of Amenhotep III, the father of Akhenaten have revealed that this pharaoh, in his lifetime, declared himself to be the living embodiment of the entire pantheon of Egyptian Gods. In this statement, the pharaoh does not disregard the other Gods, but declares himself as the embodiment of those Gods - hence no other god do I know for you but myself.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}}
